When I feel low motivation to study or like I can't focus I use the pomodoro technique, set a short timer ( fir around 30 minutes max ) and tell myself I only need to study for 30 minutes. Sometimes I get into it and continue even after the timer has rang. If I don't, I give myself a five minute break then set another for 25 minutes , and keep repeating till I get to 10 . By the time I complete 10 I'd have spent a bit over an hour and a half studying , then a longer break to gather energy for the next cycle .

I like to study biology and I have recently learned some facts about the human nervous system that justified my long-time methods: music and teaching. 🎸🎓  The explanation for the former is simply put that it keeps us aware and awake while studying, avoiding that mindless state (especially helps me because I write a lot), mostly having to do with the ascendent activator reticulate system. Some people find music and sound in general distracting, but there's also the phenomenon of colateral inhibition (we "drown out" the sounds because the brain identifies more important stimuli: the stuff we see or feel we are writing) which can occur voluntarily to some extent.   Secondly, teaching helps information remain in our long-term memory because as social animals, any information we remember and then utilise in social interactions is automatically deemed relevant and thus is more easily kept in memory. To some extent, social interactions while studying also have similar effects to music: keeping you "awake" and preventing you from slacking off, those being good reasons some people work together (just don't do it with your crush because all your brain will focus on is romance, unless you exercise great control).  For people who have made it this far, I'd like to finish with some encouragement: there are many reasons to study, it obviously makes you a better person, but not just mentally, also physically. This stuff is still ongoing research, but it is widely considered that training your brain actually makes it better (kinda like muscle, although not as evidently) in functional organisation, increasing speed of reaction and formulating ideas, even in structure (more dendrites, postmembrane receptors and neurotransmitter vesicles). 🧠

My best tip is to do the problems that the professor assigns, even if they do not count for your grade.  Do the problems over and over again.  Each time you redo a problem, you are learning the process.  Redo all the examples given in class.  To do well in math, you must treat it like a sport, practice! practice! practice!  Write out each formula before you attempt a problem.  You will be amazed when test time comes, you will have the formulas memorized.  In short, there are no shortcuts in math.  You can not look at a problem and completely comprehend it.  Just do it!

My study tips come from the mind of a senior high schooler.  But I don't think the factual study tips are any different in how they are practiced college, aside from manifesting these more seriously than ever before.  Anki (if you make the flashcards right) can help in memorization.  Notability (on iPad) can also be beneficial as a substitute for physical notes.  Use tools such as PhotoMath (to check your answers if answer keys are not provided for review; not all math textbooks have answer keys at the back, while some only provide for odd-numbered exercises), Desmos, Mathway to explain crucial technicalities.  Also, I believe music can help; I have a personal preference on listening to compositions by TheFatRat and movie soundtrack composers.  Make sure you have a place designated for studying. Some Study Tips!!: Active Recall and Space Repetition are the two concepts that will guide your study processes. All your favorite study techniques follow these concepts Active recall is like challenging your brain to think really hard about a lesson. The act of thinking really hard helps you remember even better in the long-term. - a good example of active recall are practice tests and questions. These questions challenge your bare knowledge (no textbook, no notes) to answer a questions about a topic. Active recall makes you think really hard. There are more study techniques that follow active recall.  Spaced Repetition takes advantage of how our brain works. Once we first learn a concept, we forget after an hour. If we review this concept an hour later, we will forget after another day. If we review after a day, we will forget after three days and so on. Search up the "Forgetting Curve" for specifics. This forgetting curve is basically your time schedule for studying information to cement it in your brain.  - Flashcards take advantage of this pretty well. Some apps like Anki and RemNote already make the flashcards spaced out for you.   Hope this Helps! I would suggest to do your own research.

Studying tricks that helped me:  Pomodoro Technique, I did 20/5, so 20 minutes of focused studying/work and 5 minute breaks. After doing that 3 times I'd take a longer break of 15 mins  No distractions, turning off all notifications on your phone, putting your phone in another room, don't have discord or Twitter or anything that could possibly distract you on your computer.  Doing work in a dedicated room or setting, it's helped me getting into the mindset of studying if I worked in a specific spot.  Listening to music that doesn't have lyrics. Listening to music helps me study, and I typically use the same playlist for studying so that it gets me in the mindset. Try not to have music with lyrics as it may distract you  Allocating a specific time of each day or certain days to study. You don't want your studying to overlap with other things you need to do.

1. Time management: throughout the day, write down any due dates or tasks you get and once a day, transfer these items to a master calendar that you then use to plan your days  2. If the teacher publishes their slides, use those to take notes on (print ahead of time or use a tablet)  3. Use any study guide or practice test provided. If nothing's provided ask if they can make one or if they can suggest certain problems from homework/the book that would help you study.  4. Find good study spots early in the semester. Coffee shops, study rooms that you can reserve, random computer labs that nobody uses... It's worth finding these now so you don't waste time trying to find a free table at a crowded library later  5. For notes: I write the main concept as well as steps for solving a problem, then a couple example problems. I like to highlight the main concepts and steps in different colors. This really helps my memory and to keep things organized in my head. It also makes it easy to look through old notes and make a quick practice test with those example problems or flash cards with those main concepts  6. Network with the other students. Find out if there's a discord anyone uses. Get there early for class and stay late. Talk to the other students during these times, especially the first few classes. The information and connections you get during these times can be incredibly useful  7. Take advantage of office hours  8. study the course material before the lecture so that you can use that time to ask questions and not just take notes and try to figure out what they're talking about  Good luck everyone! Some tips I wish I knew before hand: 1. Get homework out of the way: Stay on campus after your class and go to a quiet study place to get the HW for the class out of the way while the lecture is fresh in your mind.  2. Stay ahead of the schedule: Syllabus week is your best friend get a head start on material while everyone else is serial chilling that way exam study becomes easy. 3. Talk to the person next to you in class: Before class starts communicate with everyone around you get their contact and when HW gets hard collaborate. 4. Practice: This one is self-explanatory but mark out when exams are as soon as you get a list of exam dates and practice everyday until you reach every exam date.  5. Google calendar is your best friend please use that or a physical agenda. Your brain can only store so many dates, events, and times

For students who struggle with memorizations, i have a tip for you which is to use flashcards. Basically they're little piece of notes where you write questions on one side and answer on the other side. You can easily find them at bookstores or if not, just cut a big paper into several small square pieces, each about 5cm long.   What you want to do next is write the equations on one side of the flashcards, then flip them over and write the name of the equation on the other side.   For example, i wanna memorize the Equation of State. On one side, i write "what is the equation of state?", then i flip the card, and write the equations on the other side.   Once you're done writing the flashcards, put them together like a little deck, make sure the questions side are facing up, maybe shuffle them and begin to answer the questions written on them. Once you're done with one, flip the card and check whether you got it right or not.   If you get it right, place the card down on the table, which side face up doesn't matter.   If you didn't get it right, memorize it again then put it at the back of the stack of cards, question side facing you. Repeat till you finish every card.   You can even just start out with only 5 cards and eventually expand it till you get all the equations.   This really helps me as i have memory issues and I absolutely suck at remembering things. I hope it helps you too  Edit: oh and make sure you review the cards often. Like, i do it 3 times a day toward exams. Once you remembered everything the exam will feel like a breeze

I typically do small bursts of focused studying, repeatedly over the week. For example, I wanted to understand and memorize the basic Calculus differentiations and integrations, I simply read the list (e.g. Dx sinu = cosu, Dx cosu = -sinu) over the course of the day, not even trying to memorize it but rather be overly familiar with it that instinctively and eventually you would memorize it. You would also be able to identify patterns or series or sequence from the material you are studying. So a day of studying would be something like reading something over for about 30 minutes and do some on hand calculations, rest and relax and do whatever or what you need to do for as long as you wish (know your priorities though, spend your time wisely, know what is important), then go back to reading. Do that over the course of the day, for weeks, for months, for the whole semester.  Surely this would not work for some people, and alternatively it would work well for some too. Just do what you think is best for you. The essence of this process is to be saturated with the material you need to learn, expose yourself to information that you need to know. You do not need to understand it immediately, but try to be familiar first, then understand. In the end, it would be ingrained into instinct and everything would be immensely easier for you.  Best of luck to your endeavors! :))

TLDR: 1. Study outside of your room 2. Set a timer for like 15-30 minutes to study then take a break 3. On your breaks walk, get water, play a simple game 4. Make a to-do list  5. While studying listen to white noise or instrumental. I mean you can listen to lyrics but I don't because it can be distracting. I prefer silence, it feels weird at first, but it also helps you really focus 6. Study with people to keep you accountable or don't lol if you get easily distracted 7. If you're tired take a nap for 5-10 minutes or stop for the day, you're not being productive, just accept it and sleep 8.  Youtube videos are good but don't be afraid to ask a friend, classmate, tutor or teacher/professor for help 9.  Turn off all your notifications 10. Use a timer on your laptop/desktop instead 11. Don't study while hungry, I would say you can take a break to eat but then you could get distracted 12. Don't be afraid to say no to people, sometimes you have to study instead of hanging out and good friends will understand that. I call it ✨hermit mode✨ 13. Practice a lot, if it's not fun do you really understand it? jk kinda, for me when I finally understand like a math or science concept it's kinda fun, so  keep that in mind 14. Don't overstuff your brain. 15.  Write down concepts you don't fully get/understand 16. SLEEP, BROOOOOOOOOO if you don't sleep well all your efforts are in vain 17. Make a schedule of your entire day if you procrastinate easily, that way you have time to study and stuff and don't have to cram 18. If you didn't do good in a class specifically like math or science, where everything you learn is built on each other study over break, I know it's not fun but it's better than trying to catch up later. If you can, make a roadmap on what topics you are going to cover in your class. I studied calculus BC last year without taking the class and with my most prior knowledge being pre-calc. The only way I could prepare myself and keep track of everything I needed to understand and/or memorize before the exam was by writing down all of the topics I needed to cover (and there were a lot of topics, especially more niche ones after midway through Calc BC itself). It also allowed me to address what gaps I had in my knowledge so that I could know what to learn.  Usually your professor will have a syllabus before hand and my DE teacher was kind enough to give a topic list to study before every exam. But for my case I had to look online. If you were to do AP/CLEP exams the CollegeBoard does provide these resources online (albeit a much more detailed list of what you'd need to learn). I'd recommend this video for people who need a general idea of what exactly is in the first 2 levels of calculus: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eWM9mGsgTD0  Of course I used this channel to learn each of the concepts I prioritized individually :). I find for maths these things really helped me I got a 1st last year:  1. Having two notebooks, one for rough scribbles and one for smart writing is really useful. I use the rough book in class and use a smart notebook for revision. Your smart notebook should be written in a way that YOU understand! I highly recommend the Leuchtturm1917 notebooks they're such a pleasure to write on, once you tried one you'll never want to go back.  2. Colour code your revision notes in the smart notebook. I use a Bic pen (multi-pen) which comes with 4 colours. It makes it a lot quicker than having lots of different pens. The key that worked for me is: - Black: General writing  - Blue: Laws - Green: Important Actions - Red: Don't forget! Sure, it might seem slow at first but when i took the time to make neat notes i was surprised how much I used them as a resource that I still refer back to from previous semesters.  3. Use different media sources, invest in a good textbook and work through that, if you're an engineering student I highly recommend getting Engineering Mathematics by KA Stroud. Also,  watch videos with each section, seeing different approaches not only makes problems easier but gives you a greater appreciation for the wider subject.  4. Study with or teach others - Working through problems together or helping someone else helps solidify eveything you  know already and helps explore alternatives.   5. Get a subscription to a maths solver like Symbolab (just don't use it in the exam haha) being able to break down a problem and see exactly where you're going wrong.  6. Use a second brain technique, have a document on your phone to put down all your ideas, so you don't forget them, have a eureka moment while shopping? Put it in your second brain!  7. When you watch videos, set playback speed to 0.75 speed and turn subtitles on.   Always ask questions and seek help when you need it. Don't be afraid to make mistakes, make them an experience you can learn from. Never lose your enthusiasm to learn more, it may seem bitter medicine at first but eventually you start enjoying the subject and get a positive feedback loop going. You got this! Good luck everyone in your studies!

How to study math subjects: 1. Take down class notes in notebook 1, examples being the most important. 2. Study class notes then study physical/e-book topics or look up topics related to class notes. Books usually cover all sorts of variations (of problems) which may not be covered in class. 3. Solve problems in some scratch paper and transfer solved problems to another physical notebook (notebook 2). Work your way up from the easiest to the hardest/more obscure problems so as to be prepared for however difficult problems may come up in the test. 4. Put important formulas to be memorised and some useful tips in an index card. Notice that the purpose of notebook 2 is for you to understand the PROCESS while the index card's purpose is for MEMORISATION. You can go back to your index card whenever you forget a formula or want to memorise a dozen of things instead of going through numerous pages of the notebook. 5. Study in advance future topics. 6. Refresh and go back to finished lessons every few days or so for retention. *Notebook 1 only contains class notes and could look a little confusing sometimes. Notebook 2 contains solved problems and is far more presentable compared to notebook 1. I use a binder notebook that only has a few pages for every subject, but adequate, as my notebook 1. Notebook 2 is a separate notebook which has a lot of room for you to write as many problems as you want (see step 2, second sentence).

When I study for my classes, the one tip that more and more people need to hear, in my opinion, that personally helped me to ace every class in my first semester (including biology 2) is that, if you can teach the class to someone else, then you are pretty much guaranteed to ace the class.  The reason why is because I have found that, in college, you need to know more than just general concepts.  You need to know the details and UNDERSTAND those details in terms of the broader concepts and connections between those broader concepts.  Finally, if you can find a way to enjoy the class itself (maybe you don’t like the professor, but that’s not what I’m talking about), you are most likely going to find that it is exceptionally easier to be able to teach the class to someone else (like I talked about above).  That is why I believe that I did very well on the midterm and final exam in the biology lab, for example, where the averages were an F and a D-, respectively.

01-) Setting a timetable that has my breaks and sleep time prioritized.  02-) Write notes in class and review them whenever I can.  03-) Do lots of practice papers, but I get afraid to depend on them too much because most of the time they cover the  general topics and leave out the small details or less important lessons.  04-) Read the curriculum's check-up list, tick whatever I know and re-study whatever I don't.  05-) Expand my knowledge from videos on the net. Your videos were particularly useful, a TON of thanks for that.  06-) Take quizzes and tests as seriously as finals.  07-) Study the hard topics early in the morning like around before dawn and keep the easy topics after I come back home.  08-) Avoid caffeine drinks and resort to fresh juices. (I don't stay up late, preferring early morning) 09-) Read textbooks other than those required, usually from higher years up. 10-) Try explaining topics to my friends. Especially ones I learned and are still fresh to spot weaknesses. 11-) While doing practice papers, I spot repeated mistakes especially in subjects like chem and maths and jot them down and read them everyday. I helps keep the list in my mind. 12-) Studying in different places. It helps me concentrate. For example, I study math in a quiet library where I can focus, biology in the balcony where I can memorize.   I am still a freshman, and I am thinking about one of biochem, genetics and calculus. In your Question at 1:20 = the Answer to that question for me is to simply be active in that class. Most get distracted or bored and that's not good. You should be active all the time, Although you are not participating by raising your hand. You will learn as you understand the lesson itself. And also get keywords, to memorize the main concept of a lesson faster. Then find little details that might come up as a question in an exam. And that's why most of my test/quiz scores are either a pass or perfect even. Some of my classmates were very confused about how I was doing it despite my not participating in the discussion before. And that's the question they need to answer for themselves. And now here I am, Even though it's Christmas Break. Still studying math because it's my favorite of all. It's quite fascinating that I can solve these wtf questions with ease and simplicity. Most of my classmates can't, most are very dependent on the teacher's teaching and depend on what technique they use. And that's a problem, because what if one particular problem needs to be solved differently compared to the example the teacher gave? for example and my infamous one of all: 1.) Factor x^4 + 6x^2 - 27 = 0 and solve for x. Now our teacher said to JUST use synthetic division all throughout, and that's exhausting, right? you also need to find the right number whose remainder is 0 to use synthetic division again and again until it's not possible anymore. So LITERALLY my whole class is trying that exactly and that's why they take so much time to solve. So how about me? Substitution like you teach me: Now the problem x^4 + 6x^2 - 27 = 0 Let's say A = x^2, then A^2 = x^4. So the problem will look like this: A^2 + 6A - 27 = 0 /// Now it's a normal trinomial equation, so let's solve. Find 2 numbers that multiply to -27 but add to 6. The answer is 9 and negative 3 since 9 x -3 = -27 and also 9 + (-3) = 6. So: (A + 9)(A - 3) = 0 /// Now let's replace A with x^2 again. = (x^2 + 9)(x^2 - 3) = 0 /// So that's it! [Maybe (x^2 + 9) can be factored to (x + 3i)(x - 3i)] so x = 3i (since it will be the square root of -9) and the other x equals the square root of 3 since 3 is not a perfect square. And that's it, literally... Better than spamming the synthetic division... And since I advance and quickly learn all of the lessons in our grade level (which is 10). I'm very easily distracted so I've come up with ways to stay on task. I start studying a week before the test/Exam 1. make sure I eat a lot before studying so my focus wont be shifted to the fridge every 10 minutes. 2. I give my phone to my roommate and tell them to only give it back after a certain amount of time (depending how long I plan to study that day) (this helped me detox from social media too!) 3. First thing I do is work on the practice test or exam provided by the teacher. (if they do not provide past tests, course hero is excellent for finding past tests in almost every class) 4. when I'm having difficulty with a question I put a star and go to the next question  5. once I'm done I will fully review the topic of every question that has a star   6. when I say fully review that means, reading the textbook section , doing textbook problems UNTIL I'm comfortable with the material, if the textbook doesn't help I come straight to this channel. 7. to properly study using your video content I find it best to try and do each example before you go over it, to really see if I understand (the feeling when I get the same answer as you is amazing)  I am second year electrical engineering student and with this method I'm getting A's in majority of my classes. I have three things I usually do when I study. One is for memorizing things, one is for general studying, and the last is for math. 1) When you need to memorize things like functional groups, chemical reactions, taxonomies, or really anything like that, write it out several times as you say it. I once heard that seven times is enough but I usually shoot for 20 to be safe. I then test myself until I get all of them right. If I don't, I right them again. It's time consuming but it works because it uses writing, reading, speech, and hearing all at the same time. 2) Read through chapters once just to go through the material. Then go through it again and make your own notes on it in your own words. If something is still a little confusing, get help or watch a few videos. 3) Do all the examples in your book, then do them again. If you can go through the examples with no problem then move on to problems at the end of the chapter. Bonus) This is really useful in math but can help in any subject. Once you know how to do a problem, learn to do it quick. Time yourself or race your friends in the class to finish problems quickly. The point is to be able to do problems to point that they are intuitive and you don't have to think too hard on them. I know I usually overthink math problems and end up getting them wrong. Less chance to doubt your answer=less chance to mess it up.  Edit) I'm taking biostatistics, genetics, O Chem 2, and molecular biology next semester.

I always found studying for a test/exam over the course of several days to be extremely helpful. For example, if I knew I had an exam coming up in the following week, I would plan to study only certain topics of the course each day following up to the exam, usually starting anywhere from 5-7 days before the actual test. Breaking up the topics into separate days makes it easy to know when to stop studying for each day and avoid overwhelming yourself. Then on the last day before the test I would go back and review all the sections, but quicker, as a final recap before exam day. I think purposefully breaking up study sessions over several days and scheduling them for yourself can be very helpful. I know it worked for me!

@TheOrganicChemistryTutor  My brain retains information well while reading and writing. I usually set a duration of two weeks before a big evaluation, and what I do is, for 30 minutes, I re-read all my notes for a chapter, then I try to "blurt" (write down) all the info I remembered on a separate piece of paper.
